head.title: Fast Food and Obesity in America

hedline.hl1: Fast Food and Obesity in America

block.p: Paul Krugman (''Girth of a Nation,'' column, July 4) correctly expresses the enormous threats, physical and financial, of epidemic obesity.
Paul Krugman (''Girth of a Nation,'' column, July 4) correctly expresses the enormous threats, physical and financial, of epidemic obesity.

Uncertainties regarding the death toll of obesity are being exploited by corporate interests eager to suggest that the whole crisis is nothing but hype contrived by a public health community out to curtail personal liberties.
As Mr. Krugman points out, this is nonsense.

In just the span of my own career, I have watched obesity drag adult-onset diabetes into the ranks of 10-year-olds and under. I dread but do not doubt the day that it may similarly haul heart disease into the early 20's, if current trends persist.
Therefore, we simply cannot allow current trends to persist.

When Oklahoma is beachfront property, consensus regarding global warming will have come too late. So, too, if we delay responding to the obesity crisis until its death toll is incontestably clear to all.
David L. Katz, M.D. New Haven, July 4, 2005
The writer is director of the Prevention Research Center, Yale University School of Medicine.
